details.title: A New Real-Time Reliability Prediction Method for Dynamic Systems Based on On-Line Fault Prediction
details.standardTitle: A New Real-Time Reliability Prediction Method for Dynamic Systems Based on On-Line Fault Prediction

p: Zhengguo Xu received his B.Eng. in electrical engineering in 2002 from Changsha Electric Power University, and the Ph.D. degree in control science and engineering in 2009 from Tsinghua University. He is currently at the Department of Control Science and Engineering at Zhejiang University. His research interests include reliability analysis for complex systems, real-time reliability analysis, and failure prognostics.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Autom., Tsinghua Univ., Beijing, China
authors.name: Zhengguo Xu

p: Yindong Ji received his B.Eng., and M.Sci., both from the Department of Automation, Tsinghua University, in 1985, and 1989, respectively. He is currently an Associate Professor of the Department of Automation, and Vice Dean of Research Institute of Information Technology (RIIT), Tsinghua University. Prof. Ji publishes widely with over 40 journal publications in the areas of digit signal processing, fault diagnosis, and control engineering.

Donghua Zhou (M'99–SM'99) received his B.Eng., M.Sci., and Ph.D. degrees all from the Department of Electrical Engineering, Shanghai Jiaotong University, in 1985, 1988, and 1990, respectively. He was an Alexander von Humboldt Research Fellow (1995–1996) in the University of Duisburg, Germany, and a visiting Professor at Yale University (July 2001–Jan. 2002). Dr. Zhou is currently a Professor of the Department of Automation, Tsinghua University.

Dr. Zhou publishes widely with over 150 journal publications, and three monographs in the areas of process identification, diagnosis, and control. He serves the profession in many capacities such as IFAC Technical Committee on Fault Diagnosis and Safety, Deputy General Secretary of Chinese Association of Automation (CAA), and Council member of CAA. He was also the NOC Chair of the 6th IFAC Symposium on SAFEPROCESS, 2006.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Autom., Tsinghua Univ., Beijing, China
authors.name: Donghua Zhou

details.abstract: While a specific system is in use, its reliability will decrease gradually after the infant mortality period because of the components' degradation, or external attacks. Thus, reliability is a natural characteristic of a system's health, and can be used for condition monitoring & predictive maintenance. This paper introduces a new real-time reliability prediction method for dynamic systems which incorporates an on-line fault prediction algorithm. The factors that may reduce a system's reliability are modeled as an additive fault input to the system, and the fault is assumed to be varying linearly with time, approximately. The time-varying fault is roughly estimated based on a modified particle filtering algorithm at first. Then, as a time series, the fault estimate sequence is smoothed, and predicted by an exponential smoothing method. Mathematical analysis shows that the effects of the system, and measurement noises on the fault estimates are greatly reduced by exponential smoothing, which indicates that the comparatively high accuracy of the fault estimates & predictions is guaranteed. Based on the particle filtering & fault prediction results, the whole system's predictive reliability is computed through a Monte Carlo simulation strategy. The effectiveness of the proposed real-time reliability prediction method is validated by a computer simulation of a three-vessel water tank system.

links.abstract: A predictive-maintenance structure for a gradually deteriorating single-unit system (continuous time/continuous state) is presented in this paper. The proposed decision model enables optimal inspection and replacement decision in order to balance the cost engaged by failure and unavailability on an infinite horizon. Two maintenance decision variables are considered: the preventive replacement threshold and the inspection schedule based on the system state. In order to assess the performance of t...

context.text: Predictive maintenance for large, complex systems has attracted much attention both in academe, and in engineering [1]–[5].

references.title:
Continuous-time predictive-maintenance
scheduling for a deteriorating system
references.text: A. Grall, L. Dieulle, C. Brenguer, M. Roussignol, "Continuous-time predictive-maintenance scheduling for a deteriorating system", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 51, no. 2, pp. 141-150, 2002.

links.abstract: The deterioration processes of many industrial systems can be modeled in 2-phases. A 2-phase system begins its life in a new condition where it resides for a random amount of time before progressing to a worn condition where it resides for a random amount of time preceding system failure. If monitoring takes place while the system is in the worn condition, preventive maintenance is performed. This paper analyzes predictive maintenance policies for systems exhibiting 2-phase behavior, and present...

references.text: L. M. Maillart, S. M. Pollock, "Cost-optimal condition-monitoring for predictive maintenance of 2-phase systems", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 51, no. 3, pp. 322-330, 2002.

links.abstract: The predictive maintenance within the framework of intelligent-control-maintenance-management system (ICMMS) makes full use of all the information of control, maintenance, and technical management aspects to make right maintenance at the right time in the right place. In this paper, the three key elements of the predictive maintenance within the framework of ICMMS are presented. The ICMMS platform for hydroelectric generating unit, especially its maintenance function, is introduced. An artificia...

context.text: The bridge that connects reliability with life prognostics is real-time reliability evaluation & prediction, and the research in this area has developed since the early 1990s [7]–[17], [19].
Kim & Kolarik [7] firstly considered the problem of real-time conditional reliability prediction for an individual tool given its performance data.

for individual components using statistical degradation signal models
references.text: R. B. Chinnam, "On-line reliability estimation for individual components using statistical degradation signal models", Quality and Reliability Engineering International, vol. 18, pp. 53-73, 2002.

context.text: The bridge that connects reliability with life prognostics is real-time reliability evaluation & prediction, and the research in this area has developed since the early 1990s [7]–[9][17], [19].
[9] proposed a residual life distribution prediction method for the products with exponential degradation paths.

In [9], it was assumed that the prior distributions of the two parameters in the path function were two \$s\$-normal distributions, and Gebraeel [10] further generalized the conclusions to the case that the prior distribution of the two parameters was a joint \$s\$-normal distribution.
Motivated by [9], Xu & Zhou [11] studied real-time reliability prediction problem for products with general nonlinear degradation paths.

links.abstract: Research on interpreting data communicated by smart sensors and distributed sensor networks, and utilizing these data streams in making critical decisions stands to provide significant advancements across a wide range of application domains such as maintenance management. In this paper, a stochastic degradation modeling framework is developed for computing and continuously updating residual life distributions of partially degraded components. The proposed degradation methodology combines populat...

links.abstract: The purpose of this paper is to describe an approach to real-time reliability prediction, applicable to an individual product unit, operating under dynamic conditions. The concept of conditional reliability estimation is extended to real-time applications using time-series analysis techniques to bridge the gap between physical measurement and reliability prediction. The model is based on empirical measurements, self-generating, and applicable to online applications. This approach has been demons...

The concepts have been implemented using: finite-duration impulse response multi-layer perceptron neural networks for modeling degradation measures, and self-organizing maps for modeling degradation variation. The specific application considered is in-process monitoring of the condition of the drill-bit in a drilling process, using the to...

context.text: The bridge that connects reliability with life prognostics is real-time reliability evaluation & prediction, and the research in this area has developed since the early 1990s [7]–[16][17], [19].

Besides the regression analysis, and time series analysis methods, stochastic filtering was also used for real-time reliability prediction considering the uncertainties both in degradation processes, and in condition monitoring measurements [16].
In [16], the degradation process was modeled as a discrete time Markov chain.

links.abstract: This paper introduces a real-time reliability prediction method for a dynamic system which suffers from a hidden degradation process. The hidden degradation process is firstly identified by use of particle filtering based on measurable outputs of the considered dynamic system. Then the system's reliability is predicted according to the model of the degradation path. We analyze the identification algorithm mathematically, and validate the effectiveness of this method through computer simulations ...

context.text: The bridge that connects reliability with life prognostics is real-time reliability evaluation & prediction, and the research in this area has developed since the early 1990s [7]–[17], [19].
[19] considered the real-time reliability prediction problem for a dynamic system.
However, only components' degradation processes were considered in [19], so the proposed method is limited in dealing with external attacks.
And what's more, the method proposed in [19] required that the structure of the degradation path function was known in advance.
In detail, when the new measurement \${\mmb Y}_{n}\$ at time \$nT\$ becomes available, the new filtering density of the system's states can be updated as [19]  where  and .
There have been several algorithms to perform particle filtering, and a famous filter named sampling importance resampling (SIR) filter proposed in [23] is described as follows [19].

The dynamic process of the water tank system can be illustrated by the following model [19].  where  and  The variables in the above model are defined in Table I in [19], and the parameters of the above model can be found in Table II in [19].

references.text: Z. Xu, Y. Ji, D. Zhou, "Real-time reliability prediction for a dynamic system based on the hidden degradation process identification", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 57, no. 2, pp. 230-242, 2008.

context.text: Instead of the failure definition widely used in the existing real-time reliability evaluation & prediction literature, which corresponds to that the value of the fault reaches some threshold in this condition, another failure definition often used in the dynamic reliability literature [20], [21] is adopted here.

references.title:
Dynamic reliability: Toward
an integrated platform for probabilistic risk assessment
references.text: P. E. Labeau, C. Smidts, S. Swaminathan, "Dynamic reliability: Toward an integrated platform for probabilistic risk assessment", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 68, no. 3, pp. 219-254, 2000.

links.abstract: Particle methods are a set of powerful and versatile simulation-based methods to perform optimal state estimation in nonlinear non-Gaussian state-space models. The ability to compute the optimal filter is central to solving important problems in areas such as change detection, parameter estimation, and control. Much recent work has been done in these areas. The objective of this paper is to provide a detailed overview of them.

context.text: As an excellent nonlinear filtering algorithm, particle filtering has been widely used for nonlinear dynamic systems' state estimation in control & signal processing areas [22], and it provides a strong support for the whole approach proposed in this paper.

references.title:
Particle methods for change
detection, system identification, and control
references.text: C. Andrieu, A. Doucet, S. S. Singh, V. B. Tadi, "Particle methods for change detection system identification and control", Proceedings of the IEEE, vol. 92, no. 3, pp. 423-438, 2004.

links.abstract: An algorithm, the bootstrap filter, is proposed for implementing recursive Bayesian filters. The required density of the state vector is represented as a set of random samples, which are updated and propagated by the algorithm. The method is not restricted by assumptions of linearity or Gaussian noise: it may be applied to any state transition or measurement model. A simulation example of the bearings only tracking problem is presented. This simulation includes schemes for improving the efficien...

context.text: There have been several algorithms to perform particle filtering, and a famous filter named sampling importance resampling (SIR) filter proposed in [23] is described as follows [19].

context.text: The sequence of the primary fault estimates is a time series, and it can be processed using established time series analysis methods such as exponential smoothing [25].
Thus, one of the linear additive trend forecasting models, the Holt's method [25], is adopted to process the primary fault estimates.

Given the primary fault estimates \$\mathhat{\alpha}_{n}(n=1, 2, \cdots)\$ provided by the OTK-SIR algorithm, the smoothed fault estimates can be computed by [25]  and  where \$0<a<1\$ & \$0<b<1\$ are parameters for Holt's method.
